newsitem.title: TAIWAN: Taiwan central bank warns caution on stock rally.
newsitem.headline: Taiwan central bank warns caution on stock rally.

text.p: Taiwan's Central Bank Deputy Governor Hsu Chia-tung said on Saturday individual investors, especially those using margin loans in trading, should exercise caution following recent stock market rallies.

"Individual investors, especially those using margin loans in trading, should 'think about danger when reaching highs'," Hsu told journalsts when replying questions about his comments. He was speaking after the stock market closed 1.38 percent higher on Saturday at a six-year high.
The index ended up 108.39 points to 7,983.71, off an intraday high of 8,000.32.
It was the market's highest close since it ended at 8,059.14 on May 16, 1990.
Hsu declined to directly say whether the central bank will adjust its monetary policy due to the market's rally.
"We will review our monetary policy according to the consumer price situation, financial stability and the condition of the economic recovery," he said.
Hsu said inflation has so far remained under control, while there are "mixed viewpoints on how well the domestic economy is recovering."
Taiwan's consumer price index rose 1.96 percent year-on-year in January.
The central bank has forecast 1997 CPI growth of 3.31 percent year-on-year, while the cabinet's Council for Economic Planning and Development has set a 1997 CPI target of 3.0 percent.

The island's gross domestic product rose 6.62 percent year-on-year in the fourth quarter of 1996. This showed a gradual recovery compared with GDP growth of 5.12, 5.42 and 5.61 percent, respectively, in the first, second and third quarter of 1996.
